description.narrative: The Recipient will facilitate cross-organizational networking and mentoring for a cohort of 20 Emerging Wildlife Conservation Leaders (EWCL) while conducting training and guiding concrete, innovative conservation projects. Participants will be competitively selected by the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW) and partners.

participating-org.narrative: International Fund for Animal Welfare, Inc.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

receiver-org.narrative: International Fund for Animal Welfare, Inc.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

description.narrative: The Recipient will: (1) complete seasonal surveys providing an updated state of knowledge on the population and conservation status of the orangutan population and their habitat within the Danau Sentarum National Park region; (2) build on current efforts to reduce the rate of conversion and therefore fragmentation of the remaining orangutan habitat in and around the National Park through (a) implementation of a community and government awareness program, (b) development of a conservation plan and collaborative monitoring system, and (c) development of a participatory land-use plan; and (3) continue to strengthen law enforcement on illegal trade, poaching and other threats to orangutans through (a) the development of a joint agreement at the park and/or district level that incorporates local traditional rules, and (b) capacity and knowledge building including a training workshop for 20 law enforcement personnel and two intensive capacity building activities for 30-40 law enforcement personnel.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

description.narrative: "The Recipient will enter into a cooperative agreement with the Division of International Conservation (DIC) to deliver the 2013/2014 Emerging Wildlife Conservation Leaders (EWCL) program. The program will undertake a two year intensive training for approximately 20 early career wildlife professionals in essential conservation, networking and leadership skills. The Recipient will host three training sessions, two at White Oak Conservation Center in Florida and one in Washington, DC, where participants receive classroom based training from top conservationists in the field as well as mentoring and career guidance. After the first training session, participants form groups to plan, implement, and evaluate a two year international conservation campaign benefitting an endangered species. DIC involvement includes:. providing hands-on participation in program implementation,. engaging in regular dialogue and communications with EWCL,. reviewing criteria and participating in selection of the trainees who focus on international wildlife conservation,. recommending and helping select international projects for conservation campaigns, and. sharing materials including EWCL training presentations."

title.narrative: Protegiendo y Manejando Hbitat de Invernada de Aves Playeras: Ruta Pacifico

description.narrative: This project will use information gathered to locate and protect critical sites for shorebirds. Objectives are to secure the legal protection of 2130 acres of shorebird habitat, reduce the disturbance experienced by shorebirds on over 260,000 acres in 8 WHSRN sites, increase knowledge about the impacts of habitat loss on shorebirds populations wintering along the Pacific Flyway, and increase the capacity of local groups and national agencies in 9 countries to assess shorebird populations and implement management practices beneficial to shorebird habitat.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Protegiendo y Manejando Hbitat de Invernada de Aves Playeras: Ruta Pacifico

description.narrative: Urban and commercial development, aquaculture and human disturbances are among main threats to habitat sites used by Red Knots, Whimbrels, Western Sandpipers, Dunlins and other shorebird species wintering along the Pacific flyway. In 2011, the Migratory Shorebird Project (MSP) established an international partnership to understand and reverse those and other causes of shorebird declines along the Pacific Flyway. This project will use information gathered by MSP to locate and protect critical sites for shorebirds. Objectives are to secure the legal protection of 2130 acres of shorebird habitat, reduce the disturbance experienced by shorebirds on over 260,000 acres in 8 WHSRN sites, increase knowledge about the impacts of habitat loss on shorebirds populations wintering along the Pacific Flyway, and increase the capacity of local groups and national agencies in 9 countries to assess shorebird populations and implement management practices beneficial to shorebird habitat.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Conserving Birds Through the Caribbean Birding Trail

description.narrative: The goal of the Caribbean Birding Trail is to raise awareness across all communities, particularly those in or near critical bird habitat, of the regions biodiversity and the imperative to protect what remains of habitat that supporting neotropical migrants such as the Bicknells Thrush, Swainsons Warbler, Whimbrel and Greater Yellowlegs. BirdsCaribbean will use grant and match funding to advance this effort by developing a comprehensive guide training program on environmental interpretation and bird and plant identification; creating interpretive materials to build awareness about sites; and conducting environmental education trips to inform local residents about the value of the birds and their habitat, and the contribution bird-related tourism can make to a sustainable economy in the Caribbean.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

description.narrative: The goal of the Caribbean Birding Trail is to raise awareness across all communities, particularly those in or near critical bird habitat, of the regions biodiversity and the imperative to protect what remains of habitat that supporting neotropical migrants such as the Bicknells Thrush, Swainsons Warbler, Whimbrel and Greater Yellowlegs. BirdsCaribbean will use grant and match funding to advance this effort by developing a comprehensive guide training program on environmental interpretation and bird and plant identification; creating interpretive materials to build awareness about sites; and conducting environmental education trips to inform local residents about the value of the birds and their habitat, and the contribution bird-related tourism can make to a sustainable economy in the Caribbean.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Conserving a Boreal Icon: the Canada Warbler

description.narrative: With 80 percent of its breeding range in the Boreal Forest and a wintering range in tropical forests of the Andes, the Canada Warbleris an icon for both boreal and tropical forest conservation. Analysis of Breeding Bird Survey data shows a loss of 61 percent of its Canadian population. In 2013, project partners began developing a range-wide conservation initiative to benefit Canada Warbler and co-occurring migratory and resident species. The initiative seeks to build on emerging science regarding the warblers decline, and implement partner-based priority actions for the species and its habitats. Immediate objectives are to determine the winter distribution and identify priority areas and major threats to the species; improve understanding of winter ground ecology and responses to habitat management; build awareness of the importance of Canada Warbler habitat conservation among key stakeholders; and establish a partnership to implement a full lifecycle conservation strategy.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Cooperation In Conservation: Western Hemisphere Migratory Species Initiative

description.narrative: This grant will specifically co-finance the following WHMSI activities: A steering committee meeting with participants from up to 8 countries, 4 conventions and 10 NGOs; building support for the global flyways resolution of the CMS COP in Ecuador in November 2014 which contains the work plan for the Western Hemisphere and business partnership for all important actors; 1 day meeting strategy meeting prior to Convention on Migratory Species (CMS) Conference Of Parties (COP) in Ecuador in November 2014; Side event at CMS COP; Quarterly updates to WHMSI Council and partners; Updates to WHMSI web pages and working groups (marine, flyways); Keeping WHMSI.net updates functional and a usable portal in the community; Planning for a full WHMSI Council meeting; Brochure and informative dissemination of materials; Expanding development and sustainability activities; Recruiting targeted WHMSI partners from NGOs, philanthropic sector, civil society. Funding also is provided for travel expenses, administrative support, and outreach.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: CONSOLIDATING A HEMISPHERIC PLAN FOR THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY

description.narrative: Building on earlier work, the grantee will finalize the development of a second phase business plan by engaging Latin American stakeholders in refining the conceptual model; identifying and prioritizing strategies and projects; and aligning the plan with existing national and regional plans. The long-term goal is to create a platform for the recovery of shorebird populations within the Atlantic Flyway that by 2025 maintains or increases both the extent and values of shorebird habitat compared to 2015, and increases target shorebird populations by 10%.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: CONSOLIDATING A HEMISPHERIC PLAN FOR THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY

description.narrative: This project will finalize the development of a second phase business plan by 1) engaging Latin American stakeholders in refining the conceptual model, 2) identifying and prioritizing strategies and projects, and 3) aligning the plan with existing national and regional plans, with the long-term goal of creating a platform for the recovery of shorebird populations within the Atlantic Flyway, that by 2025 1) Maintains or increases both the extent and values of shorebird habitat compared to 2015, and 2) Increases target shorebird populations by 10%. This will be achieved by holding a series of meetings with key stakeholders in the Caribbean and South America to revise the current conceptual model, incorporating strategies and activities identified by stakeholders; building a broad hemispheric partnership of partners actively engaged in the development and implementation of the business plan; and, integrate the business plan with existing national, regional and species-specific shorebird conservation plans.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

description.narrative: wetlands and grasslands in the prairie pothole regions of Manitoba. 2012-3: Securement 5,930 acres, Enhancement 150

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: BUILDING THE SUSTAINABILITY OF NEOTROPICAL GRASSLANDS

description.narrative: Partners will build the ecological, economic and social sustainability of the conservation of Neotropical grassland dependent birds throughout Latin American through the development, documentation and dissemination of best management practices and the completion of the Latin American component of a Prairies to Pampas conservation business plan. This will be achieved by developing techniques and approaches to grassland conservation at key migration stopover sites; demonstrating and documenting responsible production approaches to natural grasslands conservation within rancher communities and policy environments in Latin America; building support for the conservation and sustainable use of natural grasslands through disseminating information; and engaging Latin American stakeholders in developing the conceptual model for the business plan, and integrating the plan with existing planning exercises.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

description.narrative: Grassland-dependent bird species have declined more than any other avian group in North America and are the most threatened group of migratory birds in South America. These declines are being driven by habitat loss due to agricultural expansion and intensification, over-grazing, and altered fire regimes. Fortunately, many declining grassland species can co-exist with bird-friendly agricultural practices. This project will enhance conservation of neotropical and resident grassland dependent birds throughout Latin American through the development, documentation and dissemination of best management practices and the completion of the Latin American component of a grasslands conservation business plan. Benefitted species include Swainsons hawk, American golden plover, upland sandpiper, buff- breasted sandpiper, dickcissel, and bobolink...

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: DEVEL OF A PACIFIC AMERICAS FLYWAY SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION BUSINESS PLAN I

description.narrative: This proposal is for Phase I of a two-year project to develop a Pacific Americas Flyway Shorebird Conservation Business Plan. In Phase I, we propose to convene an international planning committee to develop and refine a conceptual model with input from key partners in Central and South America, Mexico, the United States and Canada. We will use the methods of the Open Standards for the Practice of Conservation, including the Miradi model-building software, and convene two workshops for partner input. Phase II will include the completion and publication of the full Pacific Americas Shorebird Conservation Business Plan. Based on the success of other flyway strategies, we believe a comprehensive flyway approach is the only way to effectively conserve long-distance migrants.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

description.narrative: An effective strategy for flyway-scale conservation of long-distance migrant shorebirds must integrate international cooperation, conservation interventions, and monitoring across the full suite of geographic, ecological, and cultural landscapes. Although there are numerous shorebird conservation plans in place within the Pacific Flyway, these plans cover various geographies and there is no comprehensive, integrated full life- cycle plan for a representative suite of migrants. This project is for Phase I of a two-year project to develop a Pacific Americas Flyway Shorebird Conservation Business Plan. In Phase I, partners will convene an international planning committee to develop and refine a conceptual model with input from key stakeholders in Central and South America, Mexico, the United States and Canada. This project will help conserve many bird species, including snowy plover, red knot, hudsonian godwit and marbled godwit...

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

description.narrative: Understand how shorebirds use habitats within the Gulf of Fonseca Region of Central America. person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

description.narrative: The Pacific Americas Shorebird Conservation Strategy (Strategy) (Senner et al. 2016) was developed with engagement from 85 shorebird experts and resource managers in 15 countries of the flyway. Audubon is coordinating efforts to build out and facilitate wide implementation of the Strategy, link the Strategy to international lending institutions and identify potential partners and funders. During Strategy development, participants ranked shrimp aquaculture as a high threat to shorebirds in the Neotropical region and recommended creating conservation initiatives with natural resource industries as an effective way to address this threat. Along the Pacific coast of Central America, partners will further develop the Strategy with respect to shorebirds using natural and converted mangrove forests and related intertidal habitats, including shrimp aquaculture sites. A Shrimp Aquaculture Working Group-comprised primarily of non-U.S. stakeholders will be formed with support from a Latin American project coordinator. They will: (a) assess shorebird status and distribution relative to shrimp aquaculture operations and management practices, and (b) summarize the best available information on impacts to shorebirds, as well as best management practices for shorebird-friendly operations. This will create a strategic approach for implementing projects directly addressing shrimp impacts and opportunities on shorebirds on the Pacific coast of Central America.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Strengthening East Pacific leatherback conservation through regional coordination of monitoring, outreach, and policy efforts

description.narrative: The purpose of the project is to strengthen the East Pacific leatherback conservation program throughout its range. The East pacific leatherback nests in Mexico, Costa Rica and Nicaragua and migrates and forages along the East Pacific from Mexico south to Chile. The nesting population was once the largest in the world, with over 150,000 nests estimated in the early 1980s. This has plummeted to fewer than 1500 nests annually. The intent of this project is to support the EP leatherback conservation network (Laud OPO) in its efforts to improve nesting beach and bycatch reduction projects and to support the Secretariat of the Inter-American Sea Turtle Convention (IAC) in meetings with high level government decision makers to address bycatch reduction measures in range state countries. Activities include: (1) ensure regional database, website and online library of best management practices is maintained for the EP leatherback network; (2) facilitate alignment of IAC leatherback taskforce priorities with EP leatherback network as Chair of the IAC leatherback task force: (3) accompany IAC Secretariat as technical expert to meetings with high level government officials to discuss EP leatherback conservation issues and policy issues to address leatherback fisheries bycatch; and (4) coordinate one EP leatherback network workshop annually to review ongoing projects and activities and consult about problems and needs.

title.narrative: Engaging Ember-Wounaan Indigenous Communities in Reforestation and Alternative Livelihoods: Model of Community-Based Conservation in the Darien (II).

description.narrative: Conducting a public campaign to build a conservation constituency in the region; reforestation with native trees, including commercially valuable trees and shade-grown coffee, as an alternative to poaching and deforestation; strengthening of local organizations to increase capacity to manage incentive agreements; training community members in agroforestry, wildlife monitoring, and forest patrolling; developing land use co-management plans in two indigenous communities that include no-take zones around harpy eagle nesting sites and securing their ratification from the Ministry of Environment; and (6) building a coalition of national and international partners to scale up conservation efforts across the Darien region.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: A COASTAL SOLUTIONS NETWORK FOR THE PACI

description.narrative: Cornell Lab of Ornithology proposes to integrate a network to implement the Pacific Americas Shorebird Conservation Strategy with conservation actions in five priority sites in Latin America (Mexico, Chile and Colombia). Partners will restore and manage at least 27,181 acres of key habitats to reduce impacts on priority species of shorebirds, implement capacity building for conservation leaders in Latin America, and conduct outreach campaigns to create social support for these efforts. Specific actions include 1) habitat management - 27,181 acres restored through instream flows and improved hydrological connectivity, 494 acres managed through community agreements, 2471 acres managed for shorebird conservation, 172 acres managed to reduce disturbance and 494 acres improved through best management practices, 2) monitoring and research - assess vulnerability of priority habitats due to extreme weather events, conduct population surveys of migratory and breeding shorebirds as an indicator of success, and 3) education and outreach - train 24 leaders for wetland conservation in Latin America along the Pacific Flyway, engage and train 50 community leaders and stakeholders on key site governance and protection, and environmental education and awareness for the conservation of migratory birds through workshops and bird festivals reaching at least 500 people.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry
